"To you, Mr.. Chairman, belongs the high
privilege of transmitting, unimpaired, to
posterity, the fair character and liberty OF
our country. Do you expect to execute this
high trust by trampling, or suffering to be
trampled down, law, justice, the constltu-
ticn, and the rights OF other people! BY ex-
hibiting examples of inhumanity and cruel
ty, and ambition! When the minions of des-
potsm heard, in Europe, of the seizure OF
Pensacola, how did they chuckle, and chide
the admirers OF our institutions, tauntinsly
pointing to the demonstration of spirit OF
injustice and aggrandizement made by our
country, in the midst of an amicable negoci-
alton of spirit of injustice and aggrandize-
mcnt made by our country, in the midst OF
amicable negotiation. Behold said they, the
conduct of those who are constantly re.
preaching Kings You saw how those adj
mirers were astounded and hung their heads.
You saw, TOO, when that illustrious man,
who prcsides over US. adopted his pacific.
moderate, and just course, how they once
more lifted up their heads with exultation
and delight beaming in their countenances
And you saw how those minions themselves
were finally compelled to unite in the gener-
al praises bestowed upon our Government.
Beware how you forfeit this exalted charac-
ter. Beware how you give fatal sanction
in this infant period Of our Republic, scarce
ly yet two score years old, to military insub'
ordinations

plants thaving killed in his day above Forty
of these gigantic animals) LAID wager that
he would 60 into the forest and pluck three
hairs out Of an elephants tail. The feat
he actually performed, and returned safely
with the trophy to his comrades. But not

turn and shoot the same animal on the IN
stant. He went accordingly with his nigh
ty roar, but never returned. He approach
ed too incautiously. and his first shot not

upon him before he could reload or make

mendous tusks through his body trampled

1t has been asserted. that Mr.. Clay's OBJ
lection to General jackson as suitable can
ddate for the high civil Office of President
is of a late date. But it will be seen by the
following extract from the Volume OF De-
bates of Congress, that as long ago as the
reriod of the discussion of the Seminole
War, so called, MIR. Clay took ground against
Gen. Jack son, that it was impossible for
him to have abandoned, by voting for the
General tor the Presidency, without the sur
render of every pretensn to political consist
ency, or to regard for the Constitution.


THE EXTRACT:


Mr.. Clay concluded an able speech on the
subject, as follows:


"He would not" he said, "trespass much
longer upon the time Of the committee; but
he trusted he should be indulged with some
few reflections upon the danger of permit
ting the conduct, on which 1t had been his
painful duty to animadvert, to pass, without
a solemn expression Of the disapprobation
of this House. Recall to your recollection.
said he, the free nations which have gone
before us. Where are they now, and how
have they lost their libertiess If we could
transport ourselves back to the ages when
Greece and Rome fourished in their great
est prosperity, and, mingling in the throng,
ask a Grecian if he did not fear some daring
military chieftain, covered with glory, some
Philip or Alexander, would one day over.
throw his liberties. Mo- 80! the confident
and indignant Grecian would exclaim, we
have nothing to fear from our heroes; our
/ liberties will be eternal. If Roman citizen
had been asked, if he did not fear the con-
oueror of Gaul might establish throne upon
the ruins of the public liberty, he would in-
stantly have repealed the unjust insnuation
Yet Greece had fallen, Caesar had passed
the Rubicon, and the patriotic arm even oil
Brutus could not preserve the liberties OF his
country!


The celebrated Madame de Stael, in he,
last and perhaps best work, has said, that
| in the very year, almost the very month
when the president OF the Directory declared
that monarchy would never show its fright
ful head in France, Bonaparte with his gren,
adiers entered the palace OF st. Cloud, and
dispensing with the bayonet, the deputies
of the people celebrating on the affairs o
the state, laid the foundations OF that vast
fabric of dcspotism which overshadowee
all Europe. He hoped not TO be misunder
stood he was far from intimating that Gen
eral Jackson cherished any design inimica
to the liberties of his country. He believed
his intentions pure and patriotic He thank
God that hc would not, but he thanked hin
still more that he could not if he would
overturn the liberties of the republic. Blu
precedents, if bad, were fraught with thu
most dangerous consequences. Man ha
been described by some Of those who hav'
treated of his nature as bundle of habits
There was one important difference be
tween the formation of habits by An indi
vidual and by governments. lie contrast
it only after frequent repetition. A singh
instance fixes the habit and determines th
direction OF governments. Against tn
alarming doctrine of unlimited discretion il
our military commanders, when applie'
even to prisoners of war, he must enter hi
protest. 1t began upon them. it would en-
on us. He hoped that our happy form c
government was destined to be perpetual
But ifi we're to be preserved, it must be b
the practice of virtue, by justice, by mod
!. cratioc, by ma9nanimity, By greatness {

Resolved, That this meeting do approve
of. and agree to support IRRiiam Herdman,

At the Federal County Meeting. held at
Christiana on Saturday last, the following
ticket was adopted and recommended to the
support of the party.


Senator-Archibald Hamilton.


Representatives. Harmon Tally, John
Caldwell, James Deakyne, Andrew p Read
ing, Jesse Boulden, John c. Corbit.

hu Jefferson, X. L. H., Manlove Hayes, st.
G. H., John Reed, w. c. G. II.


1t was Resolved that it be recommended
to the Federalists of this county, and of the
State, to withhold their support from any
candidate as Representative to Congress,
who may be favorable to the reelection OF
John Q. Adams.

Amelancholy A evidence Of the sad effect OF I'M
hrdled passion was exhibited at West Cambridge
on Tuesday last. Two brothers by the name OF
Foster. occupy one shop as shoe makers, IN that
Mace and one of whom has often given loose to
his angry feelings and INDUCED in threats against
hi brother even against his life. On the day
above mentioned, one of the brothers remarked
70 the other that h, intended to gather some
peaches from tree in the garden, wheh lne
more pas,ionate of the two declared he would
kill him ifhe did This threat was disregalded
by the brother, who gathered the peaches. On
returning to the shop some alteration ensured,
when in the heat Of passion the other stabbed hlm
with shoe knife, which sticking against one OF
his ribs prevented nsrant death, though wound
was inflicted which it is feared may prove NOR
tal The one is now under the care ofa surgeon
and the other has been committed TO await the
sentence of the law.-Bost0n Patriot.


lhsrico and the HpdianS.--A Proclama-
ton has recently been published ny two
Mexican officers, Robbins and Buckham,
near the Boundary of the United States,
which invites volunteers to Join them in hos
tile excursions against such Indian nations
as have not acknowledged the government
Of Mexico. 1t offers full pay, besides all
punder that may be obtained, and appoints
them to meet at any point south OF Red Xiv
er, and west Of the Spanish bluff, which
would bring the place within the present ju
risdction of the Arkansas. The inhumanl-
ty of such measure. we trust. would alone
be sufficient to induce our government te
wish to prevent its consequences; but be-
sides this. the Indians would doubtless be
irritated so much as to harrass or destroy
the caravan trade opened with Mexico, ovel
our southern frontler--|G. Datiy .ddp.

We are pleased to find in the Philadelphia


Aurora the following explicit contradiction OF
the unpleasant intelligence from Colombia, re-
Gently reported by an arrival at New-York. 1t
will be pewsed with satisfaction by every we'll
wshrr to the cause of freedom and good govern
ncnt.


We state upon the best authority, that the ad-


vices from Colombia, by the lAthcnian at New


York from Carthagena, as first published in some


ofthe New-York papers, are from source not
entitled to credit. Letters and papers to the
latest dates received in this city from Colombia,


uaeduiv1cally show that vito President SASrAN-


DEp continues to enjoy undiininished popularity


in that country. A perfectly good understand
! in.r subsists between him and BOLIVAR, the only


difference even ofopitjaa being that Santandcr


has never approved o the snt'-Tcpnbhcan tca'


lures in the Bolivian constitution. lie has, how


ever, earnestly insisted upon the continuance OF


the I.iberator in the station of President of the


republic, and the Congress has refused to accept
I his own resignation of the vicc-presllency.


G. fp, in Ct


rebellion of Bustalucnt, or sanctioning his


attempt to separate the southern depart


ment from the republic. that all his feelings


aud scntjments were opposed to the conduct


of that officer, and Busamenti was on his


way to Colombia as prisoner to the vice


President: And the moment Bolivar heard


Of his beng taken. and tie attempted revo-


luton crushed. he countrrnanded the march


of the troops destined to quell his rcbcllious


movements IN the South of the repub'ic.--


Santander is one Of the purest republican


pat,jots in Colombia, and has never been for


an instant suspected Of peculation, that sto-


ry having been fabricated by few discon-


tented persons, who. for their own miscon-


duct. had lost or been dismissed trom OF


fce. The idea Of his 4 wing from Lima, up


on the approach Of Bolivar to Bosota, is CON


sidered idle and absurd, and sheer inven'
, tion of some worthless individual. We are
happy Thus to have it in our power TO give
. decided contradiction to the nntavorabie


news from Colombo, invented by an enemy
to her character and prosperity, ana TO adu
that affairs in that country had assumed
more auspcous aspect than fnr some time
past. We have no doubt Of the restoration


OF her peace and tranquility.

NEW JERSEY.-The convention which
assembled at Trenton on the 22d ult. COM
posed of delegates from niue of the counties,
passed thirteen resolutions, in favor of con-
vention to amend the constitution of the state
They recommend to the different towns to
hold meetings on the subject, and to petition
the Legislature.

By the y; pers notccG in cur last, whica
had Just been received at this Office, from
Buenos Ayres, we are informed OF the first
great reverse Of fortune that has befall.n |
the Argentine Navy. which cven;uAted in
the loss Of two armed brigs, one o. whhh
was commanded by Brown in person, IND
the other by the intrepid Capt, Drummo,d,
who was killed by a ~ ID. SHOT. The par
ticulars Of the affair are as follows:


On Friday the 9th April the Republic, In


depe ndencc, Congress, and Sarandi got TN.


der weigh and stood out off port. At terc'
clock they discovered the Brazilian squad
ron of 1S sail, which gave chase. About this


time the wind changed and Brown altered


his course, and SO continued until next morn


ing, when the Republic and Independence


grounded oil the point Of Santiago. All en-


desvours to get the vessels off proved aSor-


tive, and the Congress and Sarand immedl-


ately anchored near them. The cnemynow


drew up and opened fire which was re-


turned, for several hours, when they ceased


and retired, apparently with some OF their


vessels crippled. In the mean time, the


Congress had been despatched to Buenos


Ayres but the wind being light and the en-


emy opposing her. she was obliged to run


into Ensenada. During the night OF tho fth


every effort was made to get the grounded
,;+bn hp


9Th at O'Clock in the morning, the enemy


again bore down upon them and commenced


all attack by placing themselves in rakins


position: but several of the smaller vessels


were soon beaten off The Independence


and Ssrandi. had. by this time. expended


their powder, and were in Dad state; and
: finding it impossible to save the Republic,


her officers and crew were embarked on


board the Sarandi, and she was set fire to.
The enemy took possession OF the lndepcn-
dencc, which was by this time complete
wreck, and night put an end to the contest.
) During the action the most daring courage
and intrepidity was manifested by the crews
, of the Spanish vessels. The Independence
, fired 314e shot in two days A heavy fris
, ate anchored breast Of her, and commenced
r deliberate fire upon her with "a and 81 10


chain and double headed shot, Two hundred


of which struck her, and killed and wound
0 ed from so to 20 of her crew. The loss or
the part of Brown. who was himself wound
y ed. was 25 killed, and 81 wounded. ihs
e brazilian loss is said to be at least lOo

full articles.article:
DO young gentlemen study GesgrahhyS
"a day OF two since, while canal boat was
passing by this village; on the deck OF which
several gentlemen were speaking about the
beautiful situation OF Waterioo, on the Cam
ada shore, opposite this place, spruce
young gentleman, who wore cane, and
sported white beaver, begged to be in-
formed "where the battle of Waterloo was
fought" All stared at such consummate
ignorance. "Gentlemen, where's the spot"
he again inqured-none answered. Confus-
ed, he cast his eyes abaft, and discovered
the ebony hue of the cooks bright connte-
nance; the cook naturally thought the ques-
ton ought to be solved, SO as soon as he
caught the eye of the spark, he exclaimed
emphatcally, "Urot, massa," covering his
ivory with skinner, as he ran below"


The deck roared with laughter. The ''mor-
Ntifed man" rushed into the cabin. and betook
him to his books.-Biaek Rack Gaz.

soul. by keeping watchful and steady eye
to the executive; and above all by holding
to strict accountability the military branch
of the public force.


"To you, Mr.. Chairman, belongs the high
privilege of transmitting, unimpaired, to
posterity, the fair character and liberty OF
our country. Do you expect to execute this
high trust by trampling, or suffering to be
trampled down, law, justice, the constltu-
ticn, and the rights OF other people! BY ex-
hibiting examples of inhumanity and cruel
ty, and ambition! When the minions of des-
potsm heard, in Europe, of the seizure OF
Pensacola, how did they chuckle, and chide
the admirers OF our institutions, tauntinsly
pointing to the demonstration of spirit OF
injustice and aggrandizement made by our
country, in the midst of an amicable negoci-
alton of spirit of injustice and aggrandize-
mcnt made by our country, in the midst OF
amicable negotiation. Behold said they, the
conduct of those who are constantly re.
preaching Kings You saw how those adj
mirers were astounded and hung their heads.
You saw, TOO, when that illustrious man,
who prcsides over US. adopted his pacific.
moderate, and just course, how they once
more lifted up their heads with exultation
and delight beaming in their countenances
And you saw how those minions themselves
were finally compelled to unite in the gener-
al praises bestowed upon our Government.
Beware how you forfeit this exalted charac-
ter. Beware how you give fatal sanction
in this infant period Of our Republic, scarce
ly yet two score years old, to military insub'
ordinations

plants thaving killed in his day above Forty
of these gigantic animals) LAID wager that
he would 60 into the forest and pluck three
hairs out Of an elephants tail. The feat
he actually performed, and returned safely
with the trophy to his comrades. But not
satisfied with this daring specimen OF his au-
dacity, he laid another bet that he would re
turn and shoot the same animal on the IN
stant. He went accordingly with his nigh
ty roar, but never returned. He approach
ed too incautiously. and his first shot not
proving effective. the enragcd animal rushed
upon him before he could reload or make
his escape, and having first thurst his tre-
mendous tusks through his body trampled
him to acake.-IAomhson's Southern Atrt-

full articles.headline: GLEANT TNGS.
full articles.article:
On the 18th and 18th of Sept. "trade
sale" of books is to take place in Philadel-
phia. Similar sales have two or three times
occurred in Boston, and have been found OF
great advantage to the trade. The custom
is copied from England


Isaac w. Norris is appointed Warden
of the Port of Philadelphia, in the room OF
Charles Penrose, declined.


Havard University has conferred the hon
orary degree OF Doctor of Law on Bushrod
Washington of Virginia, and on Horace Bin3
ncy, of Philadelphia.


At a recent meeting of the London Soci'
ETY. Of Arts, Lieut.. Hood, of the British Nag
Wy, received large silver medal for an ice
saw, for clearing channel for ships navigat-
ing through the ice. This saw should be
known in the United States.


The Mat IF Kirginia, made under the au-
thority of the state, has recently appeared
engraved by Mr.. Tanner. The same artist
is making another on reduced scale. These
maps can only be obtained at present, from
the Office of the Secretary of state of Virgin
ia.


In the Crimea, they freeze their wine, 10
extract the water, and obtain the quintes-
sence.


1Norgan.-Several new bills of indictment
have been found in consequence of Important
disclosures having been made in the course.
of ths. late trials at Canandaigua.


Shortest Passage 6etzveen albany and W
York.--The Albany papers mention that
the steam boa. Independence arrived at that
place on "Wednesday, in eteven hours from
New York, including the usual landings.
| The receipts at the custom house. Lon
don, for three days in succession, in the
month of July, are said to have exceeded
one hundred thousand pound sterling each
| day


A farmer in the interior of New York shot
squirrel gamboling OIL the top OF his wheat,
6arrack; the wheat took fire and was con-
sumed, together with the hay in the vicinity.
! A final convention relative to ecclesiasti-
| cal afiairs, has been signed between the
Pope and the King of the Netherlands.


The remainder of the persons tried last
week at Canandaigua, N. York, for a con-
spiracy to kidnap WIN. Morgan, have been
acquitted


A young woman lately died suddenly in
Paris aged l9 years, who left behind her
paper stating that having been untaithiul to
her lover, she could bear to live no longer,
Mr.. Wing has been reelected Delegate
for the Territory of Michigan, by majority
of votes over Mr.. Biddle.


The amount of notes put into circulation
BY the Bank of the Commonwealth of Ken
tucky has been reduced to S813, ,874; to re.
deem which it is said the Bank holds indi-
vidual notes for loans to the amount of ST.
4o6,762, and real estate to the amount OF
S50,591.


Captain Franklin and DR.. Richardson, ot
the British Arctic Land Expedition, en-
barked at New York, on Saturday in the
packet ship James Cropper for Liverpool.

full articles.headline: OLD OPINION OF Mr.. CLAY.
full articles.article:
1t has been asserted. that Mr.. Clay's OBJ
lection to General jackson as suitable can
ddate for the high civil Office of President
is of a late date. But it will be seen by the
following extract from the Volume OF De-
bates of Congress, that as long ago as the
reriod of the discussion of the Seminole
War, so called, MIR. Clay took ground against
Gen. Jack son, that it was impossible for
him to have abandoned, by voting for the
General tor the Presidency, without the sur
render of every pretensn to political consist
ency, or to regard for the Constitution.


THE EXTRACT:


Mr.. Clay concluded an able speech on the
subject, as follows:


"He would not" he said, "trespass much
longer upon the time Of the committee; but
he trusted he should be indulged with some
few reflections upon the danger of permit
ting the conduct, on which 1t had been his
painful duty to animadvert, to pass, without
a solemn expression Of the disapprobation
of this House. Recall to your recollection.
said he, the free nations which have gone
before us. Where are they now, and how
have they lost their libertiess If we could
transport ourselves back to the ages when
Greece and Rome fourished in their great
est prosperity, and, mingling in the throng,
ask a Grecian if he did not fear some daring
military chieftain, covered with glory, some
Philip or Alexander, would one day over.
throw his liberties. Mo- 80! the confident
and indignant Grecian would exclaim, we
have nothing to fear from our heroes; our
/ liberties will be eternal. If Roman citizen
had been asked, if he did not fear the con-
oueror of Gaul might establish throne upon
the ruins of the public liberty, he would in-
stantly have repealed the unjust insnuation
Yet Greece had fallen, Caesar had passed
the Rubicon, and the patriotic arm even oil
Brutus could not preserve the liberties OF his
country!


The celebrated Madame de Stael, in he,
last and perhaps best work, has said, that
| in the very year, almost the very month
when the president OF the Directory declared
that monarchy would never show its fright
ful head in France, Bonaparte with his gren,
adiers entered the palace OF st. Cloud, and
dispensing with the bayonet, the deputies
of the people celebrating on the affairs o
the state, laid the foundations OF that vast
fabric of dcspotism which overshadowee
all Europe. He hoped not TO be misunder
stood he was far from intimating that Gen
eral Jackson cherished any design inimica
to the liberties of his country. He believed
his intentions pure and patriotic He thank
God that hc would not, but he thanked hin
still more that he could not if he would
overturn the liberties of the republic. Blu
precedents, if bad, were fraught with thu
most dangerous consequences. Man ha
been described by some Of those who hav'
treated of his nature as bundle of habits
There was one important difference be
tween the formation of habits by An indi
vidual and by governments. lie contrast
it only after frequent repetition. A singh
instance fixes the habit and determines th
direction OF governments. Against tn
alarming doctrine of unlimited discretion il
our military commanders, when applie'
even to prisoners of war, he must enter hi
protest. 1t began upon them. it would en-
on us. He hoped that our happy form c
government was destined to be perpetual
But ifi we're to be preserved, it must be b
the practice of virtue, by justice, by mod
!. cratioc, by ma9nanimity, By greatness {

full articles.article:
From Tie " 7. CNf0nicze.
appropriate Name.-We observe in our Ma
rine List the arrival Of the Happy Go Lucky, in
distress.
The Happy Go Lucky hath happily come
To a haven of rest from the rude Oceans foam,
Unhappy, unlucky, and sorely distrest,
Yet the Happy Go Lucky hath come for the


best;
Though her hap hath been lucky, her luck was


mishap,
And mischance, by chance, her name chances to

full articles.article:
An excellent Uatcr Power and small Farm,
within about ID miles of Wilmington, the fall
about 90 feet, saw-mill on the premises, viii be
sold on reasonable terms, or exchanged for real
estate in the Borough of,ymington. Apply ct

Aug, %, 1897 4s~-as

The Democratic Delegates for the sever
al hundreds Of this County, met at Red Lion
on Saturday last, and nominated the follow
ing perssns to compose the county ticket.


Senator.-Levi Boulden, p. II. Retire.
sen.at,Ucs.-A S. Read, b. H.-Jno.
'rorbert and Jas. Delplaine, c. H.--Benjamn
Whitelcy, w. c. c. H.-NVilliam +. Read,
N. C.. H.--.John Exten, r. l.. H.-Alexan-
der Crawf ford. A. H. Levy Court-Philip
Reybold, r.. L. H.-Jacob Faris, P H.
John Janvier, Jr. St. G. H.-John Herdman.
w. C.. c. II. SherW-William Herdman.
Coroner.-Hcnry Nining.


Resolved, That this meeting do approve
of. and agree to support IRRiiam Herdman,
the nominated Candidate for the office of
Sherif-and Henry Vnmg, the nominated
Candidate for the Office of Coroner, at the
ensuing generel election,--and we recon-
mend them to the unanimous support of the
Democratic Republicans of New Castle
County.

full articles.headline: POLITICAL
full articles.article:
At the Federal County Meeting. held at
Christiana on Saturday last, the following
ticket was adopted and recommended to the
support of the party.


Senator-Archibald Hamilton.


Representatives. Harmon Tally, John
Caldwell, James Deakyne, Andrew p Read
ing, Jesse Boulden, John c. Corbit.


SAerUs.-Geo. Houston, John Elliott.


Coroners.-John Green, James Armor.


Levy Court-Nathan Bouden, P. H., Eli
hu Jefferson, X. L. H., Manlove Hayes, st.
G. H., John Reed, w. c. G. II.


1t was Resolved that it be recommended
to the Federalists of this county, and of the
State, to withhold their support from any
candidate as Representative to Congress,
who may be favorable to the reelection OF
John Q. Adams.

T,in.ed UO0lenS. = We saw on Saturday the
first specimen Of printing on woolrn cloth, in
imitation Of the common cashmere shawls, an es-
tablishuent for the manufacture ofwhch article
is going into operation at Bloomfield, n. Jersey.
The piece we saw was omron shred Of rather
coarse fabric, upon which an experiment had
merely been made of the colors They were as
bright and handsome, however, as any we have
observed in the imported article. The gentle
man who showed us the sample, it may be worth
while to state, said that he did not want any pro-
tecting duties.-N y C0m .9dr.

Amelancholy A evidence Of the sad effect OF I'M
hrdled passion was exhibited at West Cambridge
on Tuesday last. Two brothers by the name OF
Foster. occupy one shop as shoe makers, IN that
Mace and one of whom has often given loose to
his angry feelings and INDUCED in threats against
hi brother even against his life. On the day
above mentioned, one of the brothers remarked
70 the other that h, intended to gather some
peaches from tree in the garden, wheh lne
more pas,ionate of the two declared he would
kill him ifhe did This threat was disregalded
by the brother, who gathered the peaches. On
returning to the shop some alteration ensured,
when in the heat Of passion the other stabbed hlm
with shoe knife, which sticking against one OF
his ribs prevented nsrant death, though wound
was inflicted which it is feared may prove NOR
tal The one is now under the care ofa surgeon
and the other has been committed TO await the
sentence of the law.-Bost0n Patriot.


lhsrico and the HpdianS.--A Proclama-
ton has recently been published ny two
Mexican officers, Robbins and Buckham,
near the Boundary of the United States,
which invites volunteers to Join them in hos
tile excursions against such Indian nations
as have not acknowledged the government
Of Mexico. 1t offers full pay, besides all
punder that may be obtained, and appoints
them to meet at any point south OF Red Xiv
er, and west Of the Spanish bluff, which
would bring the place within the present ju
risdction of the Arkansas. The inhumanl-
ty of such measure. we trust. would alone
be sufficient to induce our government te
wish to prevent its consequences; but be-
sides this. the Indians would doubtless be
irritated so much as to harrass or destroy
the caravan trade opened with Mexico, ovel
our southern frontler--|G. Datiy .ddp.
Singular .dfair.--on Friday Afternoon
last a lad about Ia years of age, belonBin,
to very respectable family in this city, wa
accosted at the corner of Pine and Front SITS
by a mHn who inquired his name, who hi
parents were, &c. After which, under pre-
tence of wishing the lad to convey pack
age to his father, he was induced to follow
the stranger into Margaretta- street: upo'
his arrival there, he was placed in wagon
and notwithstanding his earnest remon
STRANGE, taken to a tavern in the vicinity o
Bristol 1t being evening when they arriv
ed at the public house, this bay stealer or
dered the affrighted lad to bed, observed t
the landlord that he should call for him ear
iy In the morning. The boy was put into


room alone, but he was too much terrified t
sleep. After the family had all retired, h
stole quietly down stairs. escaped unobserv
ca, and arrived safe at the house of his anx
leus parents OH Sunday at noon.-PhH. fa.

lett Rio on the 7th June. Thus some grounds


are established for belief that hostilities
nave already ceased, and tranquility been
restored. 1t will be seen by our Argentine
news that the Banda Oriental, the great bone
of contention between these two powers, has
accepted the constitution of the General
Government, and classed herself among the
coniederated States of the Republic. How
this will operate upon the interest of the
Kind mediator, Great Britain, time must de-
velope.


We are pleased to find in the Philadelphia


Aurora the following explicit contradiction OF
the unpleasant intelligence from Colombia, re-
Gently reported by an arrival at New-York. 1t
will be pewsed with satisfaction by every we'll
wshrr to the cause of freedom and good govern
ncnt.


We state upon the best authority, that the ad-


vices from Colombia, by the lAthcnian at New


York from Carthagena, as first published in some


ofthe New-York papers, are from source not
entitled to credit. Letters and papers to the
latest dates received in this city from Colombia,


uaeduiv1cally show that vito President SASrAN-


DEp continues to enjoy undiininished popularity


in that country. A perfectly good understand
! in.r subsists between him and BOLIVAR, the only


difference even ofopitjaa being that Santandcr


has never approved o the snt'-Tcpnbhcan tca'


lures in the Bolivian constitution. lie has, how


ever, earnestly insisted upon the continuance OF


the I.iberator in the station of President of the


republic, and the Congress has refused to accept
I his own resignation of the vicc-presllency.


G. fp, in Ct


rebellion of Bustalucnt, or sanctioning his


attempt to separate the southern depart


ment from the republic. that all his feelings


aud scntjments were opposed to the conduct


of that officer, and Busamenti was on his


way to Colombia as prisoner to the vice


President: And the moment Bolivar heard


Of his beng taken. and tie attempted revo-


luton crushed. he countrrnanded the march


of the troops destined to quell his rcbcllious


movements IN the South of the repub'ic.--


Santander is one Of the purest republican


pat,jots in Colombia, and has never been for


an instant suspected Of peculation, that sto-


ry having been fabricated by few discon-


tented persons, who. for their own miscon-


duct. had lost or been dismissed trom OF


fce. The idea Of his 4 wing from Lima, up


on the approach Of Bolivar to Bosota, is CON


sidered idle and absurd, and sheer inven'
, tion of some worthless individual. We are
happy Thus to have it in our power TO give
. decided contradiction to the nntavorabie


news from Colombo, invented by an enemy
to her character and prosperity, ana TO adu
that affairs in that country had assumed
more auspcous aspect than fnr some time
past. We have no doubt Of the restoration


OF her peace and tranquility.





Getti9r into no,;cc.-The best talents ii
the world must be known in order to %
!. patronised. Man is the child of opportnnit,
, -circn,n stance either makes or mars him


but he may sometimes make circumstance
Some wears ago, young lawyer of fine tai
e ents and deep learning, and a graceful an'
I newerful crater withal settled in enc of on
A western villages. lie took no letters of in
production, and knew nobody. He waite'
= IN vain tor clients, his abilities were un
q known, and, of course, unapprcciated. A
J. length he devised plan for bringing him
n self into notice. He took a rattan, walke
over the way to Mr.. Smiths store, and with
4 cut saving word astonshed the unoticnd
c inr Mr.. Smith, with a terrible fogginS.


prosecution followed; our young lawye


made a splendid speech, showed what b


was. was fined an hundred dollars, and wa
5, Immediately retained III three suits OF i'm
c portance. He has since made large Tor
r tune by his profession.


r, II is with great pleasure we learn that N
Value, of this city, one of the unfortunat
sufferers OF St. Domingo, and formerly tn
u proprietor of large estates in that lslan6
d has had awarded to him by the French com
i missioners, the sum of $780, 900 francs, as hi


portion of the sum guaranteed by tho Hay


ten government to France for the recogH
C ton of its independence, one fifth OF whlc
y is PAYABLE the present year. M. Value ha
=. been a resident here for more than twent
. years, and has supported himself and lars
y family BY the exercise of those qualities an
u accomplishments peculiar to the frenc
+ character. Tho now upwards OF 20, he is stl
i tuning his cremona, and tripping the fanta
f.. tic toe for the instruction OF his lnveni
friends. 1t is but justice to state that. Ion
n struggling with the ills OF poverty. he hi
t ever sustained an honest and estimab
N character.-.N Hauen Herald.

NEW JERSEY.-The convention which
assembled at Trenton on the 22d ult. COM
posed of delegates from niue of the counties,
passed thirteen resolutions, in favor of con-
vention to amend the constitution of the state
They recommend to the different towns to
hold meetings on the subject, and to petition
the Legislature.

By the y; pers notccG in cur last, whica
had Just been received at this Office, from
Buenos Ayres, we are informed OF the first
great reverse Of fortune that has befall.n |
the Argentine Navy. which cven;uAted in
the loss Of two armed brigs, one o. whhh
was commanded by Brown in person, IND
the other by the intrepid Capt, Drummo,d,
who was killed by a ~ ID. SHOT. The par
ticulars Of the affair are as follows:


On Friday the 9th April the Republic, In


depe ndencc, Congress, and Sarandi got TN.


der weigh and stood out off port. At terc'
clock they discovered the Brazilian squad
ron of 1S sail, which gave chase. About this


time the wind changed and Brown altered


his course, and SO continued until next morn


ing, when the Republic and Independence


grounded oil the point Of Santiago. All en-


desvours to get the vessels off proved aSor-


tive, and the Congress and Sarand immedl-


ately anchored near them. The cnemynow


drew up and opened fire which was re-


turned, for several hours, when they ceased


and retired, apparently with some OF their


vessels crippled. In the mean time, the


Congress had been despatched to Buenos


Ayres but the wind being light and the en-


emy opposing her. she was obliged to run


into Ensenada. During the night OF tho fth


every effort was made to get the grounded
,;+bn hp


9Th at O'Clock in the morning, the enemy


again bore down upon them and commenced


all attack by placing themselves in rakins


position: but several of the smaller vessels


were soon beaten off The Independence


and Ssrandi. had. by this time. expended


their powder, and were in Dad state; and
: finding it impossible to save the Republic,


her officers and crew were embarked on


board the Sarandi, and she was set fire to.
The enemy took possession OF the lndepcn-
dencc, which was by this time complete
wreck, and night put an end to the contest.
) During the action the most daring courage
and intrepidity was manifested by the crews
, of the Spanish vessels. The Independence
, fired 314e shot in two days A heavy fris
, ate anchored breast Of her, and commenced
